Comments_List: I learned how to prove quantitative versions of theorems. I also learned how to use the probabilistic method. I learned how different fields of mathematics interact with combinatorics.
I learned the basics of Ramsey theory and the general approach of "take n big enough."
Common techniques used in solving Ramsey type problems in the field of combinatorics

I think it was possibly intimidating to some students that the class began with an overview without many proofs of statements.
However, the 4-student class was ultimately pretty fun.
It's always going to be changing because of the nature of the professor changing and choosing what to teach, so it's hard to say much productive.
Kind of disjointed, but overall a very interesting topic.

Yes!
I learned a lot and had fun.

It's likely to be a small class every semester, which is probably good for your grade and may be good or bad for your learning depending on who you are. The professor and topic changes every semester, so it's hard to really make a recommendation. Find out who's teaching it and what they're teaching before you decide.
Yes, it was probably the most interesting math class I've taken at Yale
